course_description: This course is designed to give prospective secondary mathematics teachers an opportunity to reflect on their own beliefs about mathematics and teaching mathematics. Students examine how students best learn mathematics for understanding, extension, and application. The course provides insight through reflecting on current recommendations and research, observing secondary students engaging in mathematical tasks, and analyzing how teachers orchestrate classroom discourse. The course aligns with NCTM principles and INTASC standards for improving curriculum and teaching pedagogy.

learning_outcomes.description: Students understand authentic mathematical practices and use them to engage in meaningful mathematical exploration and reflect on their own use of these practices to make inferences about how adolescents might engage in mathematical tasks.

learning_outcomes.outcome: Philosophy of Teaching and Learning Mathematics
learning_outcomes.description: Students articulate a philosophy of teaching and learning mathematics based on professional standards for teaching mathematics, moral dimensions of teaching, and INTASC standards.

Students can use curriculum guides such as NCTM content standards or Common Core State Standards to trace K-12 development of a central concept of mathematics for planning instruction appropriate to a particular grade level and topic.

Students can analyze and describe the mathematical experiences of adolescents in terms of tasks, discourse, and learning environments observed in secondary classrooms and reconcile theoretical principles with classroom reality.
Students identify a range of positions available to adolescents in mathematics classrooms and understand what it means to believe that all adolescents can learn mathematics.

graded_components.description: Reflection paper for each classroom observation visit
Responses to questions about readings and personal reflections from weekly observations
Math problem solutions with written explanations of thinking process, solution method, mathematical connections, and justification
Two papers: 'Math Autobiography' and 'Student Identities' papers, plus a 'Becoming a Teacher' project of choosing
Participation in two MEA activities to experience collegiality with teacher colleagues
Comprehensive exam covering readings and class discussions

attendance.absences_allowed: Up to 3 absences with no penalty (makeup required if observation missed)
attendance.penalty: 1% grade drop for each absence after the first three

course_policies.preparation: Prompt attendance and completion of assigned readings are crucial. Students should participate actively in discussions and ask questions about mathematics and pedagogy.
course_policies.classroom_environment: Create atmosphere where sharing of ideas is valued, mistakes and misunderstandings are part of learning process, and students feel safe expressing lack of understanding.

field_experiences.professionalism: High level of professionalism required when visiting secondary schools
procedures: Check in at school office before attending class
Do not evaluate the lesson or teacher; observe for insights into teaching and learning
Seek permission to observe students in small group work
Take field notes outside classroom after observation

course_policies.late_assignments: 10% grade deduction for each class period late
